history.content:
For getting your resume noticed, I believe there are resources at Berkeley (HKN, TBP, Career Center), that will help you with proofreading your resume. I would definitely recommend getting a few extra eyes on it before sending it out (If you haven't already). On your other note, although I've never done anything like it, I'm sure teaching at a coding school is super rewarding and teaches you a lot.

However, if you are interested in UI/UX and are purely focused on your resume and have a handle on web development or mobile development, I would probably suggest you work on a website/app, something that can be published, put on your resume, and explained at interviews. I would say even one project like this would help to set you apart. Of course the problem would be commitment/time management, I personally probably wouldn't have the discipline to work that 8-12 hours a week completely on a personal project.

The most straightforward UI/UX project would probably be a personal website/portfolio, but there are certainly a ton of ideas you could find online.

As a second year CS major, I was wondering if I should work part time (8-12 hours a week) at a coding school, teaching kids with scratch, python, html/css/javascript. I'll be taking 170, 188, R1B, a Design Innovation class, and lab assisting 61B.  I'm having trouble even getting interviews for internships, and need to really build my resume this semester. I'm potentially interested in UI/UX. Should I take this opportunity to work at the coding school, or should I do something else with that time? If I don't work, what can/should I do?

Note: I don't NEED to work, but extra money would make life a little easier
history.subject: Work part time or do something else?

history.content:

history.subject: Work part time or do something else?
